title: Gender stereotyping and STEM education: Girls’ empowerment through effective ICT training in Hong Kong
excerpt: For over a decade, STEM education has been developed as an integrative curriculum for promoting students’ performance in the disciplines of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. However, its development in Hong Kong is still at an early stage, and more studies are necessary to explore the impact of STEM education on local students. In addition, gender stereotyping is a long-standing issue that needs to be addressed in information communications technology (“ICT”) education. Through surveys used to evaluate a local ICT training workshop in Hong Kong with 411 female students in junior secondary school, this study provides empirical evidence supporting the effectiveness of a STEM education program for promoting student development and alleviating gender stereotyping in ICT. citation: Tam, H. L., Chan, A. Y. F., & Lai, O. L. H. (2020). "Gender stereotyping and STEM education: Girls’ empowerment through effective ICT training in Hong Kong." Children and Youth Services Review. 119(105624).
